ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Professor Brewer did a great job putting this course together, and he was also an excellent instructor during the classes. His orientation outside class and real life examples in explaining the material were something I never saw in other professors.

The class is great not only for people interested in Latin America sustaainbility, but for everyone interested in a class that is integrative and for anyone looking to expand their knowledge towards management problems regarding diverse problems.
Professor Brewer puts a lot of effort into the class and it shows. The material for each week was alwaysvery interested with a reasonable amount of readings easy to get through.
The course was very interesting, and covered a wide range of issues. I really enjoyed lectures of professors from Universidad de los Andes.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Apart from building a bridge between Latin American issues and FES, this class guest lectures were a true highlight. The visiting scholars from Colombia and Brazil were exceptional in bringing an up to date status on the sustainability issues in those countries.
The guest lecturers from Colombia.

I valued having the opportunity to meet speakers coming from Colombia. The group project was a good way to learn about the subject we were assigned. I think it is important to learn how to work in teams and this course helped me strenghten my teamwork skills.
Dr brewer knows his shit and if you care to ask him. Hell tell you the truth.
The instructor and the interaction with UniAndes.
Invited professor, Prof. Brewer, and the diversity of topics.

The guest lecturers who were brought in from the University of the Andes as experts in the topic we werefocusing on. The class focused on interdisciplinary work and did a great job of covering a range of material without seeming disorganized. It also was very effective at giving clear introductions to topics I either wasn't at all familiar with or knew only a little about. I learned a lot in this course. The group projects and final proposal were just about the only assignments and were useful activities since they kept us working consistently without being burdened. I also think they were conducive to building skills applicable after the course.
The group project was a great professional experience

1) Guess lecturers straight from Latin America was an amazing part of this course. Their experience as practitioners brought a good dynamic into class discussions and assignments. In addition, the lunch meetings that professor Brewer arranged for us with the speakers was a invaluable opportunity. Thank you prof. Brewer.2) The group projects, while sometime frustrating, they are key to learning how to coordinate things and communicate in the real world.
Guest speakers

I really liked the format of the course, in which class lectures were mixed with guest lecturers, who taught us about their experiences and areas of expertise, as well as assigned very helpful readings about these topics.I found the group project a great learning experience. It provided me an opportunity to not only learn about a specific topic in detail, but also to learn how to work with a group to produce diverse professional products.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: I think the syllabus needs to restructure the work load better along the semester. Using the same module approach, I would add the Team A and Team B assignments on the week after the guest lecture finishes. Providing a more integrated "module" than the actual concentration of student presentations at the end of the semester.

This course is dependent on four guest lecturers from Colombia and the literature they recommend. This did not provide a solid foundation in any of the topics we covered. Additional reading materials and solid lectures/discussions between the guests would have improved the course.

Even though cases from other countries were talked about. I would have liked to have more diverse speakers (from other coutries in latin-america besides Colombia and Brazil)It would be a good idea to ask speakers to provide students with methologies to do their job. Brief explanation so that if we are ever needed to work on the same thing we can be able to know where to start.
I can't think in any point for improvement.
Teacher assistant and less readings so everyone can read everything.
Sometimes the readings were repetitive, but I think the guest lecturers suggested these not the professor.

The course could be expanded to better include the urban innovations in sustainability that are occuring in South America. I hope that next year that the class can highlight innovators from a broader representation of countries.

Two things:1) I think the class could benefit greatly from Classes V2 access. Having all the readings and updates in one location is often very useful for students with many other classes and commitments going on.2) I think the assignments could be spread out more evenly throughout the semester. I felt that we had four major assignments back to back in November alone, right in between thanksgiving week and finals. Considering that a lot of these projects were group based I think having early deadlines would have avoided some of those 'off' dates when the group members are all away.NOTE - I did see how the speaker schedule somewhat dictated the deadlines for assignments and it could be hard or less beneficial for students to turn in work before the guess comes.
More precise Syllabus, better overall structure, readings should be on V2.

I feel that the class lectures in between the guest lecturers could have been, at times, better organized and structured. Also, I would have liked to spend several class periods on HOW to write professional proposals (such as reading through examples of proposals and identifying their strengths/weaknesses, etc), in order to use class time to further develop my skills in producing professional products (ie, proposals and professional presentations).I also would have liked to get written feedback on our proposals, both the preliminary and final group proposals, as well as the individual project proposals.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: It was really effective. The lectures and the readings were directed to understanding the issues in Latin America. I would make a suggestion to rename the general topics not as big tool boxes but as big challenges for sustainability. I believe this approach will benefit the domestic student mostly. It's my appreciation that a US student will find it more interesting if the issues where approached differently.
No lab sections.
N/A
We did not have labs or discussion sections. But the course lectures, readings, and speakers were all greatly compatible and interesting.
Discussions in class were interesting. I think that they could be improved if we had a better structure and syllabus, so that we could better prepare classes.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: I have a general interest in policy making for sustainable development. This class just fits that general interest. It also provides insights from a region that is not clearly represented in other FES courses or faculty interests.
I took this course because it is one of the few courses focused on Latin America. I do not think it does a solid job of discussing this area, especially as the only course to do so.
This course helped me a lot to understand sustainability problems that Latin America is facing.

I'm in the school of architecture and took this course as an elective. The architecture school offers virtually no courses that address development or developing regions, however this is where my interests lie, so what I learned in this course definitely supports my overall academic goals.

Course fits perfectly! For those of us that are attempting to focus on Latin American environmental management it is perfect. I think this class was a great addition to the FES curriculum that was up to now missing a Latin American focus (FES seems to have a lot of focus on South East Asia, China, and somewhat Brazil).
I am very interested in working in sustainability issues in Latin America, where I have developed some of my professional career. So, it is a very good fit.
I hope to specialize in Latin American issues, so this course was very germane to my interests.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I was an interesting addition to the courses I was taking towards my overall master's experience.
I wanted to learn more about sustainable development literature and projects focused in Latin America.

I took this course to keep up with my background in Latin America. I come from this region and I was looking for sharing experiences with other peers interest or coming from there. The instructor was also important when deciding to take this course; it made me trust in the quality of the class.
Because I wanted to learn more about LAtin America sustainability problems
See above

To learn about the regional trends in sustainability (low-emissions economies, local government planning, walkable/bikeable cities, waste managment, green building, clean energy, sustainable agriculture) that are being advanced throughout Latin America.
To learn about the sustainability initiatives currently underway in Latin America, specifically Colombia (my home country).
Great scope of issues in Latin America, and guest professors

I wanted to gain a better understanding of environmental issues in Latin America from practitioners in the field. Also, I wanted to improve my professional skills in writing proposals and creating professional presentations.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes. This course provides the student with a general overview of the challenges for implementing sustainability in Latin America.
No, this course taught very elementary concepts about sustainability in Latin America. It covered material that is common for undergraduate courses.
Yes
Yes.
Yes, they did.
Yes. I came in pretty open and with no specific expectations about what I would get from it, but I'm very satisfied with what I learned.

I became very knowledgeable about one topic, but would have liked more exposure to examples of "models" or "solutions" for sustainable livelihoods currently being considered. That is, what projects are considered to be successful and what are some of the elementsof that success. I would also have liked some analysis of how approaches to climate change and low-carbon development might be different in Latin America if compared to the U.S. or Europe.
They surpassed my expectations considering that we also learned aspects of business.
Yes, it met my expectations
Yes

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: In my case, this course group assignment was a true challenge. I enjoyed how difficult it was to accommodate the opposing worldviews of every teammate. The faculty guidance was helpful. I've never encountered such a thorny environment engaging as a team. I believe it was a true learning experience.

The group environment allowed me to learn about how other people approach certain concepts and problems. Unfortunately, I felt like the group did not have an even distribution of work and that other members of the group weren't as interested in learning and doing a good job as me.

Advantages - learning from people with different backgrounds and interests, and sharing knowledge and experience with the team; it was also a great experience to sharp presentation and executive summary elaboration skills.
Feedback, new ideas, learning from others and me.

I enjoyed the group assignments since they got us to get to know one another and probably lessened the overall workload. The only thing that was confusing was that Garry seemed to be a little inconsistent with feedback and because the bulk of our work was at the very end of the semester and all done collectively it was difficult to gage how we were preforming as individuals in the course.
My colleagues were impressive, thoughtful and supportive. I think we did a great job of allocating the tasks according to our interests and strengths.

Advantages:1) Sharing of ideas2) Learning group dynamics for the professional worldDisadvantages:1) Often very difficult to communicate effectively through email and setting meetings in person was very difficult as well2) Challenging to put together a reasonably sized final product without compromising material or research from someone in the group
Group work gave me the opportunity to learn from other team members experience.
It was helpful to learn how to work with group dynamics and how to assign tasks that played on each person's strengths and interests.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: You don't have to come from a Latin American country to find this class interesting. Your research doesn't need to be in the region for this class to be interesting. This class is about the challenges of sustainability in developing countries and by that it covers a lot of topics useful for many tracks or interests.

If you have a general understanding of sustainable development topics in Latin America, don't take this course. If you do take this course, be sure to start working on the group project early and make sure everyone participates.

This is a good introductory course if you are still uncertain about what you want to choose as your focus in F&ES. It is valuable if you want to have a broad picture ofall the different tools you can employ when trying to sustainably develop latin america.
Take the reading seriously, ask for more readings of your interest (it is impressive how much professor Brewer can help you with that), and definitely always participate in class.
Start working on your individual proposals from the start so you can have a great internship/ master proposal or job opportunities.

This was the one of the best courses I've taken since being at Yale and I would recommend it to anyone interested in development or Latin America. The only thing I might suggest is checking the topics the instructor intends on covering that semester since they apparently rotate. I could be worth it to take it another year if the material is more relevant to you then.
If you are interested in doing work in Latin America, definitely take the class!
Communicate often and in person with your groupAssign research/writing tasks for the group as soon as possible
to choose a good topic, and try to take advantage from the great professors that this course brings

Do as many of the readings as you can to get the most possible out of the guest lectures.Meet with Dr. Brewer outside of class to talk about class work, as well as your individual interests and job searches.
